Growth Mindset.assessmentDescription: Aspiring Andelans recognize that skill deficits they have are not a limitation but an opportunity for growth. They demonstrate an eagerness and willingness to leverage on the resources around them in order to develop holistically as a developer to take on tasks.
Growth Mindset.assessmentContext: When faced with a learning challenge...
Growth Mindset.assessmentExpectation: A blog post about my most recent challenging learning experience.

Seeks Feedback.assessmentDescription: Aspiring Andelans value receiving feedback and are able to apply feedback they receive to improve on their performance.
Seeks Feedback.assessmentContext: When given feedback verbally or in writing...
Seeks Feedback.assessmentExpectation: Screenshot of conversations showing when I requested feedback during Bootcamp. A report on an example of an experience where I benefitted from getting feedback about my work during Bootcamp

Programming Logic.assessmentDescription: Aspiring Andelans understand the fundamentals of how to break down problems into programmable logic, and be able to write reusable functions. Additionally, they will be able to identify common problem areas where the performance of a program might be affected.
Programming Logic.assessmentContext: When solving a challenge by writing logic that is repeated...
Programming Logic.assessmentExpectation: 7 Andelabs exercises from the Bootcamp category within the first week of Bootcamp. A function to generate prime numbers from 0 to n with asymptotic analysis. A function to generate Fibonacci sequence from 0 to n with asymptotic analysis

scoringContext.description: Fails to write a function that returns a value
Incorporates best practices and code optimization

Version Control.assessmentDescription: Aspiring Andelans understand what version control is and how using it can collaboration on projects more effective.
Version Control.assessmentContext: When working on a software project (Version Control Behaviors)...
Version Control.assessmentExpectation: A list of contexts where version control is useful and why

scoringContext.description: Doesn't setup Git repo to track project progress
Makes commits to head with commit message
Utilizes branching (commits, push to repo, pull requests and merges to master)

Test-Driven Development.assessmentDescription: Aspiring Andelans know what tests are, how to write them, and how the TDD approach can be beneficial in development.
Test-Driven Development.assessmentContext: When writing code for an application or feature...
Test-Driven Development.assessmentExpectation: GitHub repository with at least 10 test cases for one of factorial, Fibonacci or FizzBuzz function. GitHub repository with at least 20 test cases for OOP assignment.

Writing Professionally.assessmentDescription: Aspiring Andelans are able to recognize and describe several important differences between quality (7Cs) writing and low-quality writing. Their writing consistently shows demonstration of 5 or more of the 7 Cs. The fellow is able to recognize the appropriate tone or style for specific mediums
Writing Professionally.assessmentContext: When writing a message or blog post...
Writing Professionally.assessmentExpectation: A blog post that is easy to understand, uses correct grammar and that communicates the desired message.

Object Oriented Programming.assessmentDescription: Aspiring Andelans understand what classes and objects are, how to design simple data models, and how to apply object-oriented programming principles to solve basic problems.
Object Oriented Programming.assessmentContext: When writing code to solve a complex problem...
Object Oriented Programming.assessmentExpectation: GitHub repo containing a real-world problem modeled using OOP while taking advantage of inheritance, encapsulation, polymorphism and the other OOP concepts.

Writes classes with attributes and methods

HTTP & Web Services.assessmentDescription: Aspiring Andelans know what the Request-Response Cycle is, the difference between clients and servers, and how APIs and web services operate.
HTTP & Web Services.assessmentExpectation: A simple command line application that consumes a Public API using a HTTP client library.

Front-End Development.assessmentDescription: Aspiring Andelans are able to demonstrate effective use of HTML and CSS in designing user interfaces.
Front-End Development.assessmentExpectation: GitHub repo containing a clone of a simple user interface created using HTML and CSS.

Relationship Building.assessmentDescription: Aspiring Andelans are able to identify, approach and comfortably build rapport with Bootcampers, Fellows, Trainers, and Staff members at Andela. They understand that establishing and strengthening relationships is valuable.
Relationship Building.assessmentExpectation: Comprehensive/Informative verbal self introduction. A blog post on interesting attributes of four fellows and one member of staff I proactively interacted with within one week

scoringContext.description: Takes initiative, Supports others & Manages conflict well

Asks Questions.assessmentDescription: Aspiring Andelans see asking questions as important, and show a readiness to ask many questions in multiple situations.
Asks Questions.assessmentContext: When opportunity for asking questions arises...
Asks Questions.assessmentExpectation: A screenshot of slack conversations showing inquiry about something new.

scoringContext.description: Asks concise and effective questions in team setting

Agile Methodology.assessmentDescription: Aspiring Andelans are able to make use of the Scrum framework to manage small- to mid-sized projects with a knowledge of all the necessary terms and concepts used.
Agile Methodology.assessmentContext: When working on a software project...
Agile Methodology.assessmentExpectation: A link to an active Trello board for Bootcamp project developed using Scrum framework. Project plan for a short project that can be executed in 30 min. To be presented in class.

scoringContext.description: Doesnt break down project into tasks
Runs effective standups and sprint reviews

Adaptability.assessmentDescription: Aspiring Andelans understand that they will encounter changes in their work environment and are able to perform at a high level in the face of change.
Adaptability.assessmentExpectation: Blog post reflecting on a change-focused improv exercise and Bootcamp events that posed great changes.

Motivation and Commitment.assessmentDescription: Aspiring Andelans see high levels of motivation and commitment to objectives as good and desirable, and strive to maintain drive and determination in the face of challenges.
Motivation and Commitment.assessmentExpectation: A set objective for time and scope of delivery of Bootcamp project. Complete Bootcamp project and presentation, meeting with expectations set above

Databases.assessmentDescription: Aspiring Andelans know what SQL is, the different types of databases, examples of databases and how to design basic database tables.
Databases.assessmentExpectation: SQL database design for a simple database problem involving at least two tables with relationships. Screenshots showing results for at least 5 reports generated from the data within the database using SQL.

Makes commits to head with commit message

scoringContext.description: Does not attempt to follow Python's PEP8 or JavaScript's AirBnB syntax norms and/or the codebase is dis-organised (e.g. absense of comments) and thus is not easily understandable/naming conventions are not clear.
The code follows Python's PEP8 or JavaScript's AirBnB syntax norms, is organized appropriately (i.e. has comments to aid understanding), simple to understand and handles all edge cases.
The code follows Python's PEP8 or JavaScript's AirBnB syntax norms, is heavily commented and adheres to best practices (e.g. proper naming conventions)

Project Management.assessmentDescription: Aspiring Andelans with this skill knows how to view current, backlog and iceboxed stories, see which stories have been assigned to them, be able to update stories with an estimate and with activity undertaken on the story, and create their own stories for work that has been assigned to them outside of the tool.

Updates the tool with time/effort estimates for each assigned task, updates story cards with activity taken
